editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE next thing to the choice of your friends is the choice of your company.

There are two ≈øorts of good company, the one con≈øi≈øts of per≈øons of birth, rank and fa≈øhion; the other, of tho≈øe who are di≈øtingui≈øhed by ≈øome peculiar merit, in any liberal art or ≈øcience; as men of letters, &c. and a mixture of the≈øe is what I would have under≈øtood by good company; for it is not what particular ≈øets of people in general acknowledge to be ≈øo, and are the accredited good company of the place.

Now and then, per≈øons without either birth, rank or character, will creep into good company, under the protection of ≈øome con≈øiderable per≈øonage; but, in general, none are admitted of mean degree, or infamous immoral character.
In this fa≈øhionable good company alone, can you learn the be≈øt manners and the be≈øt language: for, as there is no legal ≈øtandard to form them by, „Äà‚óä„Äâ here they are e≈øtabli≈øhed.

It may po≈ø≈øibly be que≈øtioned, whether a man has it always in his power to get into good company: undoubtedly, by de≈øerving it he has; provided he is in circum≈øtances which enable him to live and appear in the ≈øtyle of a gentleman. Knowledge, mode≈øty and good breeding, will endear him to all that ≈øee him; for without politene≈øs, the ≈øcholar is no better than a pedant, the philo≈øopher than a cynic, the ≈øoldier than a brute, nor any man than a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ own.

Though the company of men of learning and genius is highly to be valued and occa≈øionally coveted, I would by no means have you always found in ≈øuch company. As they do not live in the world, they cannot have that ea≈øy manner of addre≈øs which I would wi≈øh you to acquire. If you can bear a part in ≈øuch company, it is certainly advi≈øeable to be in it ≈øometimes, and you will be the more e≈øteemed in other company by being ≈øo: but let it not engro≈øs you, le≈øt you ≈øhould be con≈øidered as one of the literati, which however re≈øpectable in name, is not the way to ri≈øe or ≈øhine in the fa≈øhionable world.

But the company which, of all others, you ≈øhould carefully avoid, is that, which, in every ≈øen≈øe of the word may be called
‚Ä¢ ow; low in birth, low in rank, low in parts, and low in manners; that company, who, in≈øignificant and contemptible in them≈øelves, think is an honour to be ≈øeen with you, and who will flatter your follies, nay your very vices to keep you with them

Though you may think ≈øuch a caution unnece≈ø≈øary, I do not; for many a young gentleman of ≈øen≈øe and rank, has been led by his vanity to keep ≈øuch company, till he has been degraded, villified and undone.

The vanity I mean, is that of being the fir≈øt of the company. This pride, though too common, is idle to the la≈øt degree. Nothing in the world lets a man down ≈øo much. For the ≈øake of dictating, being applauded and admired by this low company, he is di≈øgraced and di≈øqualified for better. Depend upon it, in the e≈øtimation of mankind, you will ≈øink or ri≈øe to the level of the company you keep.

Be it, then, your ambition to get into the be≈øt company; and, when there, imitate their virtues, but not their vices. You have no doubt, often heard of genteel and fa≈øhionable vices. The≈øe are whoreing, drinking and gaming. It has happened that ≈øome men, even with the≈øe vices, have been admired and e≈øteemed. Under≈øtand this matter rightly, it is not their vices for which they are admired; but for ≈øome accompli≈øhments they at the ≈øame time po≈ø≈øe≈øs; for their parts, their learning or their good-breeding. Be a≈ø≈øured, were they free from their vices, they would be much more e≈øteemed. In the≈øe mixed characters, the bad part is over-looked for the ≈øake of the good.

Should you be unfortunate enough to have any vices of your own, add not to their number by adopting the vices of others. Vices of adoption are of all others the mo≈øt unpardonable, for they have not
„Äà‚óä„Äâ inadvertency to plead. If people had no vices but their own, „Äà‚óä„Äâ would have ≈øo many as they have.

Imitate, then, only the perfections you meet with; copy the po
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tene≈øs, the addre≈øs, the ea≈øy manner of well-bred people; and remember, let them ≈øhine ever ≈øo bright, if they have any vices, they ‚Ä¢ re ≈øo many blemi≈øhes, which it would be as ridiculous to imitate, as „Äà‚óä„Äâ would to make an artificial wart upon one's face, becau≈øe ≈øome very hand≈øome man had the misfortune to have a natural one upon his.

div.head: LAUGHTER.
div.p: LET us now de≈øcend to minute matters, which though not ≈øo important as tho≈øe we have mentioned, are far from incon≈øiderable. Of the≈øe, laughter is one.

Frequent and loud laughter is a ≈øure ≈øign of a weak mind, and no le≈øs characteri≈øtic of a low education. It is the manner in which low-bred men expre≈øs their ≈øilly joy, at ≈øilly things, and they call it being merry.

I do not recommend upon all occa≈øions a ≈øolemn countenance. A man may ≈ømile, but if he would be thought a gentleman and a man of ≈øen≈øe, he would by no means laugh. True wit never made a man of fa≈øhion laugh; he is above it. It may create a ≈ømile, but a loud laughter ≈øhows, that a man has not the command of him≈øelf, every one who would wi≈øh to appear ≈øen≈øible mu≈øt abhor it.

A man's going to ≈øit down, on ≈øuppo≈øition that he has a chair behind him, and falling for want of one, occa≈øions a general laugh, when the be≈øt pieces of wit would not do it; a ≈øufficient proof, how low and unbecoming laughter is.

Be≈øides, could the immediate laugher hear his own noi≈øe, or ≈øee the faces he makes, he would de≈øpi≈øe him≈øelf for his folly. Laughter being generally ≈øuppo≈øed to be the effect of gaiety, its ab≈øurdity is not properly attended to; but a little reflexion will ea≈øily re≈øtrain it; and when you are told, it is a mark of low breeding, I per≈øuade my≈øelf you will endeavour to avoid it.

Some people have a ≈øilly trick of laughing whenever they ≈øpeak; ≈øo that they are always on the grin, and their faces are ever di≈øtorted. This and a thou≈øand other tricks, ≈øuch as ≈øcratching their heads, twirling their hats, fumbling with their button, playing with their „Äà‚óä„Äâ , &c. &c. are acquired from a fal≈øe mode≈øty at their fir≈øt out≈øet in life. Being ≈øhame-faced in company, they try a variety of ways to keep them≈øelves in countenance; thus, they fall into the≈øe awkward habits I have mentioned, which grow upon them, and in time become habitual.

Nothing is more repugnant likewi≈øe to good breeding than, hor≈øeplay of any ‚Ä¢ ort, romping, throwing things at one another's heads, and ≈øo on. They may pa≈øs well enough with the mob, but they le≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ n and degrade the gentleman.

div.head: SUNDRY LITTLE ACCOMPLISHMENTS.
div.p: I HAVE had rea≈øons to ob≈øerve before, that various little matters, apparently trifling in them≈øelves, con≈øpire to form the whole of plea≈øing, as in a well fini≈øhed portrait, a variety of colours combine to complete the piece. It not being nece≈ø≈øary to dwell much upon them, I ≈øhall content my≈øelf, with ju≈øt mentioning them as they occur.

1. To do the honours of a table gracefully, is one of the outlines of a well-bred man; and to carve well, is an article, little as it may ≈øeem, that is u≈øeful twice every day, and the doing of which ill, is not only trouble≈øome to one's ≈øelf, but renders us di≈øagreeable and ridiculous to others. We are always in pain for a man, who in≈øtead of cutting up a fowl genteelly, is hacking for half an hour acro≈øs the the bone, grea≈øing him≈øelf, and be≈øpattering the company with the ≈øauce. U≈øe, with a little attention, is all that is requi≈øite to acquit your≈øelf in this particular.

2. To be well received, you mu≈øt al≈øo pay ≈øome attention to your behaviour at table, where it is exceedingly rude to ≈øcratch any part of your body, to ≈øpit or blow your no≈øe, if you can po≈ø≈øibly avoid it, to eat greedily, to lean your elbows on the table, to pick your teeth before the di≈øhes are removed, or to leave the table before grace is ≈øaid.

3. Drinking of healths is now growing out of fa≈øhion, and is very unpolite in good company. Cu≈øtom once had made it univer≈øal, but the improved manners of the age now renders it vulgar. What can be more rude, or ridiculous than to interrupt per≈øons at their mea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with an unnece≈ø≈øary compliment? Ab≈øtain then from this ≈øilly cu≈øtom, where you find it out of u≈øe; and u≈øe it only at tho≈øe tables where it continues general.

4. A polite manner of refu≈øing to comply with the ≈øolicitations of a company, is al≈øo very nece≈ø≈øary to be learnt; for, a young man, who ≈øeems to have no will of his own, but does every thing that is a≈øked of him, may be a very good-natured fellow, but he is a very ≈øilly one. If you are invited to drink at any man's hou≈øe, more than you think is whole≈øome, you may ≈øay, "you wi≈øh you could, but that ≈øo little makes you both drunk and ≈øick, that you ≈øhall only be bad company by doing it: of cour≈øe, beg to be excu≈øed." If de≈øired to play at cards deeper than you would, refu≈øe it ludicrou≈øly; tell them, if you were ≈øure to lo≈øe, you might po≈ø≈øibly ≈øit down; but that as fortune may be favourable, you dread the thought of having too much money, ever ≈øince you found what an incumbrance it was to poor Harlequin, and therefore you are re≈øolved never to put your≈øelf in the way of winning more than ≈øuch or ≈øuch a ≈øum a-day. This light way of declining invitations to vice and folly, is more becoming a young man, than philo≈øophical or ≈øententious refu≈øals, which would only be laughed at.

5. Now I am on the ≈øubject of cards, I mu≈øt not omit mentioning the nece≈ø≈øity of playing them well and genteelly, if you would be thought to have kept company. I would by no means recommend playing at cards as a part of your ≈øtudy, le≈øt you would grow too fond of
„Äà‚óä„Äâ and the con≈øequence prove bad. It were better not to know a diamond from a club, than to become a gambler; but, as cu≈øtom has introduced innocent card-playing at mo≈øt friendly meetings, it marks ‚Ä¢ he gentleman to handle them genteelly, and play them well, and as I hope you will play only for ≈ømall ≈øums, ≈øhould you lo≈øe your money, pray lo≈øe it with temper; or if you win, receive your winnings without elation or greedine≈øs.

6. To write well and correct, and in a plea≈øing ≈øtyle, is another part of polite education. Every man who has the u≈øe of his eyes and right hand, can write whatever hand he plea≈øes. Nothing is ≈øo illiberal as a ≈øchool-boy's ≈øcrawl. I would not have you learn a ≈øtiff formal hand-writing like that of a ≈øchool-ma≈øter, but a genteel, legible, and liberal hand, and to be able to write quick. As to the correctne≈øs and elegance of your writing, attention to grammar does the one, and to the be≈øt authors the other. Epi≈øtolary corre≈øpondence ≈øhould not be carried on in a ≈øtudied or affected ≈øtyle, but the language ≈øhould flow from the pen, as naturally and as ea≈øily as it would from the mouth. In ≈øhort, a letter ≈øhould be penned in the ≈øame ≈øtyle, as you would talk to your friend if he were pre≈øent.

7. If writing well ≈øhows the gentleman, much more ≈øo does ≈øpelling well. It is ≈øo e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary for a gentleman, or a man of letters, that one fal≈øe ≈øpelling may fix a ridicule on him for the remainder of his life. Words in books are generally well ≈øpelled, according to the orthography of the age; reading therefore, with attention, will teach every one to ≈øpell right. It ≈øometimes happens that words ≈øhall be ≈øpelled differently by different authors; but if you ≈øpell them upon the authority of one, in e≈øtimation of the public, you will e≈øcape ridicule. Where there is but one way of ≈øpelling a word, by your ≈øpelling it wrong, you will be ≈øure to be laughed at. For a woman of a tolerable education would laugh at and de≈øpi≈øe her lover, if he wrote to her, and the words were ill-≈øpelled. Be particularly attentive then to your ≈øpelling.

8. There is nothing that a young man, at his fir≈øt appearance in life, ought more to dread, than having any ridicule fixed on him. In the e≈øtimation even of the mo≈øt rational men, it will le≈ø≈øen him, but ruin him with all the re≈øt. Many a man has been undone by a ridiculous nick-name. The cau≈øes of nick-names among well-bred men, are generally the little defects in manner, air, or addre≈øs. To have the appellation of ill-bred, awkward, muttering, left-legged, or any other, tacked always to your name, would injure you more than you are aware of; avoid then tho≈øe little defects, (and they are ea≈øily avoided) and you need never fear a nick-name.

9. Some young men are apt to think that they cannot be complete gentlemen, without becoming men of plea≈øure: and the rake they often mi≈øtake for the man of plea≈øure. A rake is made up of the meane≈øt and mo≈øt di≈øgraceful vices. They all combine to degrade his character, and ruin his health and fortune‚ñ™ A man of plea≈øure will ‚Ä¢ efine upon the enjoyments of the age, attend them with decency and partake of them becomingly. Indeed he is too often le≈øs ≈øcrupulous than he ≈øhould be, and frequently has the cau≈øe to repent it. A man of plea≈øure at be≈øt is but a di≈ø≈øipated being, and what the rational part of mankind mu≈øt abhor; I mention it however, le≈øt in taking up the man of plea≈øure, you ≈øhould fall into the rake: for of
two evils, always choo≈øe the lea≈øt. A di≈ø≈øolute flagitious footman may make as good a rake as a man of the fir≈øt quality. Few men can be men of plea≈øure; every man may be a rake. There is a certain dignity that ≈øhould be pre≈øerved in all our plea≈øures; in love a man may lo≈øe his heart without lo≈øing his no≈øe; at table, a man may have a di≈øtingui≈øhing palate without being a glutton; he may love wine without being a drunkard; he may game without being a gambler; and ≈øo on. Every virtue has its kindred vice, and every plea≈øure its neighbouring di≈øgrace. Temperance and moderation, mark the gentleman; but exce≈øs the black-guard. Attend carefully then to the line that divides them; and remember to ≈øtop rather a yard ≈øhort, than ≈øtep an inch beyond it. Weigh the pre≈øent enjoyment of your plea≈øures again≈øt the nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequences of them, and I will leave you to your own determination.

10. A gentleman has ever ≈øome regard al≈øo to the choice of his amu≈øements. If at cards, he will not be ≈øeen at cribbage, all-fours, or putt; or, in ≈øports of exerci≈øe, at ≈økittles, foot-ball, leap-frog, cricket, driving of coaches, &c. but will pre≈øerve a propriety in every part of his conduct; knowing that any imitations of the manners of the mob, will unavoidably ≈øtamp him with vulgarity. There is another amu≈øement too, which I cannot help calling illiberal, that is, playing upon any mu≈øical in≈øtrument. Mu≈øic is commonly reckoned one of the liberal arts, and undoubtedly is ≈øo; but to be piping or fiddling at a concert is degrading to a man of fa≈øhion. If you love mu≈øic, hear it; pay fiddlers to play to you, but never fiddle your≈øelf. It makes a gentleman appear frivolous and contemptible, leads him frequently into bad company, and wa≈øtes that time which might otherwi≈øe be well employed.

11. Secrecy is another characteri≈øtic of good breeding. Be careful never to tell in one company what you ≈øee or hear in another; much le≈øs to divert the pre≈øent company at the expence of the la≈øt. Things apparently indifferent may, when often repeated and told abroad, have much more ≈øerious con≈øequences than imagined. In conver≈øation, there is generally a tacit reliance, that what is ≈øaid will not be repeated; and a man, though not enjoined to ≈øecrecy, will be excluded company if found to be a tatler; be≈øides, he will draw him≈øelf into a thou≈øand ≈øcrapes, and every one will be afraid to ≈øpeak before him.

12. Pulling out your watch in company una≈øked, either at home or abroad, is a mark of ill-breeding; if at home, it appears as if you were tired of your company, and wi≈øhed them to be gone; if abroad, as if the hours dragged heavily, and you wi≈øhed to be gone your≈øelf. If you want to know the time, withdraw; be≈øides, as the taking what is called a French leave was introduced, that on the per≈øon's leaving the company, the re≈øt might not be di≈øturbed; looking at your watch does what that piece of politene≈øs was de≈øigned to prevent; it is a kind of dictating to all pre≈øent, and telling them it is time, or almo≈øt time to break up.

13. Among other things let me caution you again≈øt ever being in a hurry: a man of ≈øen≈øe may be in ha≈øte, but he is never in a hurry: convinced that hurry is the ≈øure≈øt way to make him do what he undertakes ill. To be in a hurry is a proof that the bu≈øine≈øs we embark
in is too great for us; of cour≈øe, it is the mark of little minds, that are puzzled and perplexed, when they ≈øhould be cool and deliberate; they wi≈øh do every thing at once, and are thus able to do nothing. Be ≈øteady then, in all your engagements; look round you, before you begin; and remember that you had better do half of them well, and leave the re≈øt undone, than do the whole indifferently.

14. From a kind of fal≈øe mode≈øty, mo≈øt young men are apt to con≈øider familiarity as unbecoming. Forwardne≈øs, I allow is ≈øo; but there is a decent familiarity that is nece≈ø≈øary in the cour≈øe of life. More formal vi≈øits, upon formal invitations, are not the thing; they create no connexion, nor will they prove of ≈øervice to you; it is the carele≈øs and ea≈øy ingre≈øs and egre≈øs, at all hours, that ≈øecures an acquaintance to our intere≈øt, and this is acquired by a re≈øpectful familiarity entered into, without forfeiting your con≈øequence.

15. In acquiring new acquaintances, be careful not to neglect your old, for a flight of this kind is ≈øeldom forgiven. If you cannot be with your former acquaintance ≈øo often as you u≈øed to be when you had no others, take care not to give them cau≈øe to think you neglect them: call upon them frequently though you cannot ≈øtay long with them; tell them, you are ≈øorry to leave them ≈øo ≈øoon, and nothing ≈øhould take you away but certain engagements which good-manners oblige you to attend to; for it will be your intere≈øt to make all the friends you can, and as few enemies as po≈ø≈øible; by friends I would not be under≈øtood to mean confidential ones: but per≈øons who ≈øpeak of you re≈øpectfully, and who, con≈øi≈øtent with; their own intere≈øt, would wi≈øh to be of ≈øervice to you, and would rather do you good than harm.

16. Another thing I mu≈øt recommend to you, as characteri≈øtic of a polite education, and of having kept good company, is a graceful manner of confering favours. The mo≈øt obliging things may be done ≈øo awkwardly as to offend, while the mo≈øt di≈øagreeable things may be done ≈øo agreeable as to plea≈øe.

17. A few more articles of general advice, and I have done; the fir≈øt is on the ≈øubject of vanity. It is the common failing of youth and ≈øuch as ought to be carefully guarded again≈øt. The vanity I mean, is that which, if given way to, ≈øtamps a man a coxcomb, a character he will find a difficulty to get rid of, perhaps as long as he lives. Now this vanity ≈øhows it≈øelf in a variety of ≈øhapes; one man ≈øhall pride him≈øelf in taking the lead in all conver≈øations, and peremptorily deciding upon every ≈øubject; another, de≈øirous of appearing ≈øucce≈øsful among the women, ≈øhall in≈øinuate the encouragement he has met with, the conque≈øts he makes, and perhaps boa≈øts of favours he never received; if he ≈øpeaks truth, he is ungenerous; if fal≈øe, he is a villain, but whether true or fal≈øe, defeats his own purpo≈øes, overthrows the reputation he wi≈øhes to erect, and draws upon him≈øelf contempt in the room of re≈øpect. Some men are vain enough to think they acquire con≈øequence by alliance, or by an acquaintance with per≈øons of di≈øtingui≈øhed character or abilities; hence they are continually telling of their grand-father lord ≈øuch-a-one; their kin≈øman Sir William ≈øuch-a-one; or their intimate friend Dr. ≈øuch-a-one; with whom perhaps they are ≈øcarce acquainted. If they are ever found out (and that they are ≈øure to be one time or other)
they become ridiculous and contemptible: but even admitting what they ≈øay to be true, what then? A man's intrin≈øic merit does not ri≈øe from an ennobled alliance, or a reputable acquaintance. A rich man never borrows. When angling for prai≈øe, mode≈øty is the ≈øure≈øt bait. If we would wi≈øh to ≈øhine in any particular character, we mu≈øt never affect that character. An affectation of courage will make a man pa≈øs for a bully; an affectation of wit for a coxcomb; and an affectation of ≈øen≈øe for a fool. Not that I would recommend ba≈øhfulne≈øs or timidity; no, I would have every one know his own value, yet not di≈øcover that he knows it, but leave his merit to be found out by others.

18. Another thing worth your attention is, if in company with an inferior, not to let him feel his inferiority; if he di≈øcovers it him≈øelf without your endeavour, the fault is not yours, and he will not blame you; but if you take pains to mortify him, or to make him feel him≈øelf inferior to you, in abilities, fortune, or rank, it is an in≈øult that will not readily be forgiven. In point of abilities it would be unju≈øt, as they are out of his power; in point of rank or fortune, it is ill-natured and ill-bred. This rule is never more nece≈ø≈øary than at table, where there cannot be a greater in≈øult than to help an inferior to a part he di≈ølikes, or a part that may be wor≈øe than ordinary, and to take the be≈øt to your≈øelf. If you at any time invite an inferior to your table, you put him during the time he is there, upon an equality with you, and it is an act of the highe≈øt rudene≈øs to treat him in any re≈øpect ≈ølightingly. I would rather double my attention to ≈øuch a per≈øon, and treat him with additional re≈øpect, le≈øt he ≈øhould even ≈øuppo≈øe him≈øelf neglected. There cannot be a greater ≈øavagene≈øs or cruelty, or any thing more degrading to a man of fa≈øhion, than to put upon or take unbecoming liberties with him, who≈øe mode≈øty, humility, or re≈øpect will not ≈øuffer him to retaliate. True politene≈øs con≈øi≈øts in making every body about you happy; and as to mortify, is to render unhappy, it can be nothing but the wor≈øt of breeding. Make it a rule rather to flatter a per≈øon's vanity than otherwi≈øe; make him, if po≈ø≈øible, more in love with him≈øelf, and you will be certain to gain his e≈øteem; never tell him any thing he may not like to hear, nor ≈øay things that will put him out of countenance, but let it be your ≈øtudy on all occa≈øions to plea≈øe; this will be making friends in≈øtead of enemies, and be a means of helping your≈øelf in the end.

19. Never be witty at the expence of any one pre≈øent, nor gratify that idle inclination, which is too ≈øtrong in mo≈øt young men, I mean laughing at, or ridiculing the weakne≈ø≈øes or infirmities of others, by way of diverting the company or di≈øplaying your own ≈øuperiority. Mo≈øt people have their weakne≈ø≈øes, their peculiar likings and aver≈øions. Some cannot bear the ≈øight of a cat; others the ≈ømell of chee≈øe, and ≈øo on; was you to laugh at tho≈øe men for their antipathies, or by de≈øign or inattention to bring them in their way, you could not in≈øult them more. to ≈øome of you. You expect they will be ≈øo ‚Ä¢ d cheap, and, perhaps, they may for le≈øs than they co≈øt; but, if you have no occa≈øion for them, they mu≈øt be dear to you.
